conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light source position.
Size of shadow is influenced by distance between object and light source; closer light source results in larger shadow, farther results in smaller shadow.
Light source is currently positioned above the objects, casting shadows on the ground.
Moving the light source backward increases distance between light source and objects.
Increased distance causes shadows to become smaller because light rays are more parallel when source is farther away.
As light source moves backward, shadows will shift slightly towards the objects due to change in angle of light rays.
Shadows will become smaller as light source moves backward due to reduced angle of incidence.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move slightly closer to their respective objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift slightly towards the objects and become smaller when light source moves backward.
